**Gibraltar** ([/dʒɪˈbrɔːltər/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/8/88/LL-Q1860_%28eng%29-Vealhurl-Gibraltar.wav/LL-Q1860_%28eng%29-Vealhurl-Gibraltar.wav.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:LL-Q1860_(eng)-Vealhurl-Gibraltar.wav "File:LL-Q1860 (eng)-Vealhurl-Gibraltar.wav")^ [*jib-RAWL-tər*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key"),
Spanish: [\[xiβɾalˈtaɾ\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish "Help:IPA/Spanish")) is a [British Overseas Territory](/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories "British Overseas Territories")^[\[a\]](#cite_note-6)^ and city^[\[6\]](#cite_note-7)^ located at the southern tip of the [Iberian Peninsula](/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula "Iberian Peninsula"), on the [Bay of Gibraltar](/wiki/Bay_of_Gibraltar "Bay of Gibraltar"), near the exit of the [Mediterranean Sea](/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea "Mediterranean Sea") into the [Atlantic Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean") ([Strait of Gibraltar](/wiki/Strait_of_Gibraltar "Strait of Gibraltar")).^[\[7\]](#cite_note-8)^^[\[8\]](#cite_note-9)^ It has an area of 6.8 km^2^ (2.6 sq mi)^[\[3\]](#cite_note-gibraltar.gov.gi-3)^ and is [bordered to the north](/wiki/Gibraltar%E2%80%93Spain_border "Gibraltar–Spain border") by [Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain") ([Campo de Gibraltar](/wiki/Campo_de_Gibraltar "Campo de Gibraltar")). The landscape is dominated by the [Rock of Gibraltar](/wiki/Rock_of_Gibraltar "Rock of Gibraltar"), at the foot of which is a densely populated town area, home to some 34,003 people, primarily [Gibraltarians](/wiki/Gibraltarians "Gibraltarians").^[\[9\]](#cite_note-10)^{#cite_ref-10}

Gibraltar was founded as a permanent watchtower by the [Almohads](/wiki/Almohad_Caliphate "Almohad Caliphate") in 1160. It switched control between the [Nasrids](/wiki/Nasrids "Nasrids"), [Castilians](/wiki/Crown_of_Castile "Crown of Castile") and [Marinids](/wiki/Marinids "Marinids") in the [Late Middle Ages](/wiki/Late_Middle_Ages "Late Middle Ages"), acquiring larger strategic clout upon the destruction of nearby [Algeciras](/wiki/Algeciras "Algeciras")  1375. It became again part of the Crown of Castile in 1462. In 1704, Anglo-Dutch forces [captured Gibraltar](/wiki/Capture_of_Gibraltar "Capture of Gibraltar") from Spain during the [War of the Spanish Succession](/wiki/War_of_the_Spanish_Succession "War of the Spanish Succession"), and it was ceded to [Great Britain](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain "Kingdom of Great Britain") in perpetuity under the [Treaty of Utrecht](/wiki/Treaty_of_Utrecht "Treaty of Utrecht") in 1713. It became an important base for the [Royal Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy"), particularly during the [Napoleonic Wars](/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars "Napoleonic Wars") and [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), as it controlled the [narrow entrance and exit](/wiki/Choke_point "Choke point") to the [Mediterranean Sea](/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea "Mediterranean Sea"), the [Strait of Gibraltar](/wiki/Strait_of_Gibraltar "Strait of Gibraltar"), with half the world's seaborne trade passing through it.^[\[10\]](#cite_note-11)^^[\[11\]](#cite_note-12)^^[\[12\]](#cite_note-13)^{#cite_ref-13}

The sovereignty of Gibraltar is a point of contention in [Anglo-Spanish relations](/wiki/Spain%E2%80%93United_Kingdom_relations "Spain–United Kingdom relations") as Spain asserts [a claim to the territory](/wiki/Status_of_Gibraltar "Status of Gibraltar").^[\[13\]](#cite_note-Maec-14)^^[\[14\]](#cite_note-15)^ Gibraltarians overwhelmingly rejected proposals for Spanish sovereignty in a [1967 referendum](/wiki/1967_Gibraltar_sovereignty_referendum "1967 Gibraltar sovereignty referendum"), and for shared sovereignty in a [2002 referendum](/wiki/2002_Gibraltar_sovereignty_referendum "2002 Gibraltar sovereignty referendum").^[\[15\]](#cite_note-16)^^[\[16\]](#cite_note-Hills-13-17)^ Nevertheless, Gibraltar maintains close economic and cultural links with Spain, with many Gibraltarians speaking Spanish as well as a local dialect known as [Llanito](/wiki/Llanito "Llanito").^[\[17\]](#cite_note-Levey2008-18)^^[\[18\]](#cite_note-19)^^[\[19\]](#cite_note-20)^{#cite_ref-20}

Gibraltar's economy rests on financial services, e-gaming, tourism and the port.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-21)^ With one of the world's lowest unemployment rates, the largest part of the labour force are resident in Spain or non-Gibraltarians, especially in the private sector. Since [Brexit](/wiki/Brexit "Brexit"), Gibraltar is not a member of the European Union but negotiations are under way to have it participate in the [Schengen Agreement](/wiki/Schengen_Agreement "Schengen Agreement") to facilitate border movements between Gibraltar and Spain.^[\[21\]](#cite_note-GibStatement-22)^ As of March 2023^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gibraltar&action=edit)^, talks seem deadlocked.^[\[22\]](#cite_note-FT240323-23)^{#cite_ref-FT240323_23-0}  

Name {#Name}
------------

The name is derived from [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language"): [جبل طارق](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D8%AC%D8%A8%D9%84_%D8%B7%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%82 "wikt:جبل طارق"), [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Arabic "Romanization of Arabic"): *Jabal Ṭāriq*, [lit.](/wiki/Literal_translation "Literal translation") 'Mount of Tariq' (named after the 8th-century North African military leader [Tariq ibn Ziyad](/wiki/Tariq_ibn_Ziyad "Tariq ibn Ziyad"), who began the [Muslim conquest of the Iberian Peninsula](/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_the_Iberian_Peninsula "Muslim conquest of the Iberian Peninsula") via the Strait of Gibraltar in 711).^[\[23\]](#cite_note-WattCachia2007-24)^{#cite_ref-WattCachia2007_24-0}  

History {#History}
------------------

Main article: [History of Gibraltar](/wiki/History_of_Gibraltar "History of Gibraltar")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/The_Moorish_Castle.jpg/220px-The_Moorish_Castle.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Moorish_Castle.jpg) View of the northern face of the [Moorish Castle](/wiki/Moorish_Castle "Moorish Castle")'s Tower of Homage  

### Prehistory and ancient history {#Prehistory_and_ancient_history}

Evidence of [Neanderthal](/wiki/Neanderthal "Neanderthal") habitation in Gibraltar from around 50,000 years ago has been discovered at [Gorham's Cave](/wiki/Gorham%27s_Cave "Gorham's Cave").^[\[24\]](#cite_note-25)^ The caves of Gibraltar continued to be used by *[Homo sapiens](/wiki/Homo_sapiens "Homo sapiens")* after the final extinction of the Neanderthals. Stone tools, ancient hearths and animal bones dating from around 40,000 years ago to about 5,000 years ago have been found in deposits left in Gorham's Cave.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-26)^{#cite_ref-26}

Numerous [potsherds](/wiki/Sherd "Sherd") dating from the [Neolithic](/wiki/Neolithic "Neolithic") period have been found in Gibraltar's caves, mostly of types typical of the [Almerian culture](/wiki/Prehistoric_Iberia "Prehistoric Iberia") found elsewhere in [Andalusia](/wiki/Andalusia "Andalusia"), especially around the town of [Almería](/wiki/Almer%C3%ADa "Almería"), from which it takes its name.^[\[26\]](#cite_note-27)^ There is little evidence of habitation in the [Bronze Age](/wiki/Bronze_Age "Bronze Age") when people had largely stopped living in caves.^[\[27\]](#cite_note-28)^{#cite_ref-28}

During ancient times, Gibraltar was regarded by the peoples of the Mediterranean as a place of religious and symbolic importance. The [Phoenicians](/wiki/Phoenicians "Phoenicians") were present for several centuries since around 950 BC, apparently using Gorham's Cave as a shrine to the *[genius loci](/wiki/Genius_loci "Genius loci")* ,^[\[28\]](#cite_note-29)^ as did the [Carthaginians](/wiki/Carthaginians "Carthaginians") and [Romans](/wiki/Ancient_Rome "Ancient Rome") after them. Gibraltar was known as *[Mons Calpe](/wiki/Mons_Calpe "Mons Calpe")* , a name perhaps of Phoenician origin.^[\[16\]](#cite_note-Hills-13-17)^ *Mons Calpe* was considered by the ancient Greeks and Romans as one of the [Pillars of Hercules](/wiki/Pillars_of_Hercules "Pillars of Hercules"), after the [Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greece "Ancient Greece") legend of the creation of the [Strait of Gibraltar](/wiki/Strait_of_Gibraltar "Strait of Gibraltar") by [Heracles](/wiki/Heracles "Heracles"). There is no known archaeological evidence of permanent settlements from the ancient period.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-30)^ They settled at the head of the bay in what is today known as the [*Campo* (hinterland) of Gibraltar](/wiki/Campo_de_Gibraltar "Campo de Gibraltar").^[\[30\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJackson22-31)^ The town of [Carteia](/wiki/Carteia "Carteia"), near the location of the modern Spanish town of [San Roque](/wiki/San_Roque,_C%C3%A1diz "San Roque, Cádiz"), was founded by the Phoenicians around 950 BC on the site of an early settlement of the native [Turdetani](/wiki/Turdetani "Turdetani") people.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-32)^{#cite_ref-32}  

### Middle Ages {#Middle_Ages}

After the collapse of the [Western Roman Empire](/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire "Western Roman Empire"), Gibraltar came briefly under the control of the [Vandals](/wiki/Vandals "Vandals"), who crossed into Africa at the invitation of [Boniface](/wiki/Bonifacius "Bonifacius"), the Count (or commander) of the territory.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

The area later formed part of the [Visigothic Kingdom](/wiki/Visigothic_Kingdom "Visigothic Kingdom") of [Hispania](/wiki/Hispania "Hispania") for almost 300 years, from 414 until 711 AD.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

Following a raid in 710, a predominantly Berber army under the command of [Tariq ibn Ziyad](/wiki/Tariq_ibn_Ziyad "Tariq ibn Ziyad") crossed from North Africa in April 711 and landed somewhere in the vicinity of Gibraltar (though most likely not in the bay or at the Rock itself).^[\[32\]](#cite_note-33)^^[\[33\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJackson21–5-34)^ Tariq's expedition led to the [Islamic conquest of most of the Iberian peninsula](/wiki/Umayyad_conquest_of_Hispania "Umayyad conquest of Hispania"). *Mons Calpe* was renamed *Jabal Ṭāriq* (جبل طارق), "the Mount of Tariq", subsequently corrupted into *Gibraltar* .^[\[16\]](#cite_note-Hills-13-17)^{#cite_ref-Hills-13_17-2}

In 1160 the [Almohad](/wiki/Almohad_Caliphate "Almohad Caliphate") Sultan [Abd al-Mu'min](/wiki/Abd_al-Mu%27min "Abd al-Mu'min") ordered that a permanent settlement, including a castle, be built. It received the name of Medinat al-Fath (City of the Victory).^[\[34\]](#cite_note-norris-35)^ The Tower of Homage of the [Moorish Castle](/wiki/Moorish_Castle "Moorish Castle") remains standing today.{#cite_ref-norris_35-0}

From 1274 onwards, the town was fought over and captured by the [Nasrids](/wiki/Nasrid_dynasty "Nasrid dynasty") of [Granada](/wiki/Granada "Granada") (in 1237 and 1374), the [Marinids](/wiki/Marinids "Marinids") of [Fez](/wiki/Fez,_Morocco "Fez, Morocco") (in 1274 and 1333) and the kings of [Castile](/wiki/Crown_of_Castile "Crown of Castile") (in 1309). Upon the Nasrid destruction and abandonment of [Algeciras](/wiki/Algeciras "Algeciras")  1375 and Nasrids' procurement of Gibraltar away from Marinids in 1375, the Nasrids favoured Gibraltar (a worse natural harbor than Algeciras but featuring better defence capabilities) as a military and urban outpost in the Strait, although Gibraltar did not ever reach a large population during this period.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-36)^{#cite_ref-36}  

### Modern era {#Modern_era}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Spain_and_Portugal-_handbook_for_travellers_%281901%29_%2814589975490%29.jpg/220px-Spain_and_Portugal-_handbook_for_travellers_%281901%29_%2814589975490%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Spain_and_Portugal-_handbook_for_travellers_(1901)_(14589975490).jpg) [Baedeker](/wiki/Baedeker "Baedeker") map of Gibraltar, 1901

In 1462, Gibraltar was [captured](/wiki/Eighth_Siege_of_Gibraltar "Eighth Siege of Gibraltar") by [Juan Alonso de Guzmán, 1st Duke of Medina Sidonia](/wiki/Juan_Alonso_de_Guzm%C3%A1n,_1st_Duke_of_Medina_Sidonia "Juan Alonso de Guzmán, 1st Duke of Medina Sidonia"), from the [Emirate of Granada](/wiki/Emirate_of_Granada "Emirate of Granada").^[\[36\]](#cite_note-37)^{#cite_ref-37}

After the conquest, [Henry IV of Castile](/wiki/Henry_IV_of_Castile "Henry IV of Castile") assumed the additional title of [King of Gibraltar](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Gibraltar "Kingdom of Gibraltar"), establishing it as part of the *[comarca](/wiki/Comarca "Comarca")* of the [Campo Llano de Gibraltar](/wiki/Campo_de_Gibraltar "Campo de Gibraltar").^[\[37\]](#cite_note-38)^ Six years later, Gibraltar was restored to the Duke of Medina Sidonia, who sold it in 1474 to a group of 4,350 *[conversos](/wiki/Converso "Converso")* (Christian converts from Judaism) from [Cordova](/wiki/C%C3%B3rdoba,_Spain "Córdoba, Spain") and [Seville](/wiki/Seville,_Spain "Seville, Spain") and in exchange for maintaining the garrison of the town for two years, after which time they were expelled, returning to their home towns or moving on to other parts of Spain.^[\[38\]](#cite_note-39)^ In 1501, Gibraltar passed back to the Spanish Crown, and [Isabella I of Castile](/wiki/Isabella_I_of_Castile "Isabella I of Castile") issued a [Royal Warrant](/wiki/Royal_warrant_(document) "Royal warrant (document)") granting Gibraltar the coat of arms that it still uses.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-39}

In 1540 Gibraltar was captured and ransacked by [Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") admiral [Hayreddin Barbarossa](/wiki/Hayreddin_Barbarossa "Hayreddin Barbarossa").^[\[39\]](#cite_note-Hernandez-40)^^[\[40\]](#cite_note-41)^ The raid of the small town eliminated nearly an entire generation of Gibraltarians.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-Hernandez-40)^{#cite_ref-Hernandez_40-1}

In 1704, during the [War of the Spanish Succession](/wiki/War_of_the_Spanish_Succession "War of the Spanish Succession"), a combined [Anglo](/wiki/Kingdom_of_England "Kingdom of England")-[Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_Republic "Dutch Republic") fleet, representing the [Grand Alliance](/wiki/Grand_Alliance_(League_of_Augsburg) "Grand Alliance (League of Augsburg)"), [captured the town of Gibraltar](/wiki/Capture_of_Gibraltar "Capture of Gibraltar") on behalf of the [Archduke Charles of Austria](/wiki/Charles_VI,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Charles VI, Holy Roman Emperor") in his campaign to become King of Spain. Subsequently, most of the population left the town, with many settling nearby.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-42)^ As the Alliance's campaign faltered, the 1713 [Treaty of Utrecht](/wiki/Treaty_of_Utrecht "Treaty of Utrecht") was negotiated, which ceded control of Gibraltar to Britain to secure Britain's withdrawal from the war. Unsuccessful attempts by Spanish monarchs to regain Gibraltar were made, with the [siege of 1727](/wiki/Siege_of_Gibraltar_(1727) "Siege of Gibraltar (1727)"), and again with the [Great Siege of Gibraltar](/wiki/Great_Siege_of_Gibraltar "Great Siege of Gibraltar") (1779 to 1783), during the [American War of Independence](/wiki/American_War_of_Independence "American War of Independence").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-42}

After the destructive Great Siege, the town was almost entirely rebuilt.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-At_an_architectural_crossroads-43)^ Giovanni Maria Boschetti, who arrived in Gibraltar in 1784 as a 25-year-old from Milan, where he is thought to have been a stonemason or engineer, built the Victualling Yard (completed in 1812) and many other buildings. Boschetti is regarded as having been responsible for setting the old town's style, described by Claire Montado, chief executive of the Gibraltar Heritage Trust, as "military-ordnance-style arched doorways, Italianate stucco relief, Genoese shutters, English Regency ironwork balconies, Spanish stained glass and Georgian sash and casement windows."^[\[42\]](#cite_note-At_an_architectural_crossroads-43)^{#cite_ref-At_an_architectural_crossroads_43-1}

During the [Napoleonic Wars](/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars "Napoleonic Wars"), Gibraltar became a key base for the [Royal Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy") and played an important role leading up to the [Battle of Trafalgar](/wiki/Battle_of_Trafalgar "Battle of Trafalgar") (21 October 1805). Designated one of four [Imperial fortresses](/wiki/Imperial_fortress "Imperial fortress") (along with [Halifax, Nova Scotia](/wiki/Halifax,_Nova_Scotia "Halifax, Nova Scotia"), [Bermuda](/wiki/Bermuda "Bermuda"), and [Malta](/wiki/Malta "Malta")),^[\[43\]](#cite_note-44)^ its strategic location made it a key base during the [Crimean War](/wiki/Crimean_War "Crimean War") of 1854--1856. In the 18th century, the peacetime military garrison fluctuated in numbers from a minimum of 1,100 to a maximum of 5,000. The first half of the 19th century saw a significant increase of population to more than 17,000 in 1860, as people from Britain and all around the Mediterranean -- Italian, Portuguese, Maltese, Jewish and French -- took up residence in the town.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-45)^{#cite_ref-45}

Its strategic value increased with the opening of the [Suez Canal](/wiki/Suez_Canal "Suez Canal"), as it lay on the sea route between the UK and the [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") east of Suez. In the later 19th century, major investments were made to improve the fortifications and the port.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-46)^{#cite_ref-46}  

### Contemporary history {#Contemporary_history}

See also: [Military history of Gibraltar during World War II](/wiki/Military_history_of_Gibraltar_during_World_War_II "Military history of Gibraltar during World War II") and [Effect of Brexit on Gibraltar](/wiki/Effect_of_Brexit_on_Gibraltar "Effect of Brexit on Gibraltar")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Douglas_DC-3_of_BOAC_at_Gibraltar%2C_silhouetted_by_searchlights_on_the_Rock.jpg/220px-Douglas_DC-3_of_BOAC_at_Gibraltar%2C_silhouetted_by_searchlights_on_the_Rock.jpg)](/wiki/File:Douglas_DC-3_of_BOAC_at_Gibraltar,_silhouetted_by_searchlights_on_the_Rock.jpg) Shown here during the Second World War, a [Douglas Dakota](/wiki/Douglas_Dakota "Douglas Dakota") of [BOAC](/wiki/BOAC "BOAC") is silhouetted at Gibraltar by the batteries of searchlights on the Rock, as crews prepare it for a night flight to the United Kingdom.

[During the Second World War](/wiki/Military_history_of_Gibraltar_during_World_War_II "Military history of Gibraltar during World War II"), most of Gibraltar's [civilian population was evacuated](/wiki/Evacuation_of_the_Gibraltarian_civilian_population_during_World_War_II "Evacuation of the Gibraltarian civilian population during World War II"), mainly to London, but also to parts of [Morocco](/wiki/Morocco "Morocco") and [Madeira](/wiki/Madeira "Madeira") and to [Gibraltar Camp](/wiki/Gibraltar_Camp "Gibraltar Camp") in [Jamaica](/wiki/Jamaica "Jamaica"). The Rock was strengthened as a [fortress](/wiki/Fortification "Fortification"). On 18 July 1940, the [Vichy French](/wiki/Vichy_France "Vichy France") [air force](/wiki/Vichy_French_Air_Force "Vichy French Air Force") attacked Gibraltar in retaliation for the [British bombing](/wiki/Attack_on_Mers-el-K%C3%A9bir "Attack on Mers-el-Kébir") of the Vichy navy. The naval base and the ships based there played a key role in the provisioning and supply of the island of [Malta](/wiki/Malta "Malta") during [its long siege](/wiki/Siege_of_Malta_(World_War_II) "Siege of Malta (World War II)"). As well as frequent short runs, known as "Club Runs", towards Malta to fly off aircraft reinforcements (initially [Hurricanes](/wiki/Hawker_hurricane "Hawker hurricane"), but later, notably from the USN aircraft carrier *[Wasp](/wiki/USS_Wasp_(CV-7) "USS Wasp (CV-7)")* , [Spitfires](/wiki/Supermarine_Spitfire "Supermarine Spitfire")), the critical [Operation Pedestal](/wiki/Operation_Pedestal "Operation Pedestal") convoy was run from Gibraltar in August 1942. This resupplied the island at a critical time in the face of concentrated air attacks from German and Italian forces. Spanish dictator [Francisco Franco](/wiki/Francisco_Franco "Francisco Franco")'s reluctance to allow the [German Army](/wiki/Wehrmacht "Wehrmacht") onto Spanish soil frustrated a German plan to capture the Rock, codenamed [Operation Felix](/wiki/Operation_Felix "Operation Felix").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Gibraltar_Naval_dockyard_and_South_Mole.JPG/220px-Gibraltar_Naval_dockyard_and_South_Mole.JPG)](/wiki/File:Gibraltar_Naval_dockyard_and_South_Mole.JPG) Buildings of the former [HM Dockyard, Gibraltar](/wiki/HM_Dockyard,_Gibraltar "HM Dockyard, Gibraltar"), dating from the 1895 expansion

In the 1950s, Franco renewed Spain's claim to sovereignty over Gibraltar and restricted movement between Gibraltar and Spain. Gibraltarians voted overwhelmingly to remain under British sovereignty in the [1967 Gibraltar sovereignty referendum](/wiki/1967_Gibraltar_sovereignty_referendum "1967 Gibraltar sovereignty referendum"), which led to the passing of the [Gibraltar Constitution Order](/wiki/Gibraltar_Constitution_Order_1969 "Gibraltar Constitution Order 1969") in 1969. In response, Spain completely closed the border with Gibraltar and severed all communication links.^[\[46\]](#cite_note-Jordine2009-47)^ The border with Spain was partially reopened in 1982 and fully reopened in 1985 before Spain's accession to the [European Community](/wiki/European_Community "European Community").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-Jordine2009_47-0}

In the early 2000s, Britain and Spain were in negotiations over a potential agreement that would see them sharing sovereignty over Gibraltar. The government of Gibraltar organised a [referendum](/wiki/2002_Gibraltar_sovereignty_referendum "2002 Gibraltar sovereignty referendum") on the plan, and 99% of the population voted to reject it.^[\[47\]](#cite_note-48)^^[\[48\]](#cite_note-49)^ In 2008, the British government committed to respecting the Gibraltarians' wishes.^[\[49\]](#cite_note-50)^ A [new Constitution Order](/wiki/Gibraltar_Constitution_Order_2006 "Gibraltar Constitution Order 2006") was approved in referendum in 2006. A process of tripartite negotiations started in 2006 between Spain, Gibraltar and the UK, ending some restrictions and dealing with disputes in some specific areas such as air movements, customs procedures, telecommunications, pensions and cultural exchange.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-51)^{#cite_ref-51}

In the [British referendum on membership of the European Union](/wiki/British_referendum_on_membership_of_the_European_Union "British referendum on membership of the European Union") 96% of [Gibraltarians voted to remain](/wiki/Gibraltarians_voted_to_remain "Gibraltarians voted to remain") on an 84% turnout.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-52)^ Spain renewed calls for joint Spanish--British control of the peninsula;^[\[52\]](#cite_note-53)^ these were strongly rebuffed by Gibraltar's Chief Minister.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-54)^ On 18 October 2018, however, Spain seemed to have reached an agreement with the United Kingdom in relation to its objections to Gibraltar leaving the EU with the UK, with Spain's prime minister [Pedro Sánchez](/wiki/Pedro_S%C3%A1nchez "Pedro Sánchez") stating, "Gibraltar will no longer be a problem in arriving at a Brexit deal."^[\[54\]](#cite_note-55)^{#cite_ref-55}

On 31 January 2020, the [UK left the European Union](/wiki/Brexit "Brexit") and [consequently](/wiki/Effect_of_Brexit_on_Gibraltar "Effect of Brexit on Gibraltar") so did Gibraltar. Under the terms of the transition phase in the [Brexit withdrawal agreement](/wiki/Brexit_withdrawal_agreement "Brexit withdrawal agreement"), Gibraltar's relationship with the EU continued unchanged until the end of 2020 when it was replaced by the [EU--UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement](/wiki/EU%E2%80%93UK_Trade_and_Cooperation_Agreement "EU–UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement"). On 31 December 2020, the UK and Spain agreed in principle on a basis for the EU and the UK to negotiate an agreement through which Gibraltar would participate in the [Schengen Area](/wiki/Schengen_Area "Schengen Area"),^[\[21\]](#cite_note-GibStatement-22)^ to avoid a hard border with Spain. The arrangements have not entered into force.^[\[21\]](#cite_note-GibStatement-22)^^[\[55\]](#cite_note-BBC_News-56)^^[\[56\]](#cite_note-Ashifa_Kassam-57)^^[\[57\]](#cite_note-58)^{#cite_ref-58}

In 2022, Gibraltar launched a bid for city status as part of the [Platinum Jubilee Civic Honours](/wiki/Platinum_Jubilee_Civic_Honours "Platinum Jubilee Civic Honours"). The bid was refused, but when researchers looked through [the National Archives](/wiki/The_National_Archives_(United_Kingdom) "The National Archives (United Kingdom)"), they found that it had already been recognised as a city by [Queen Victoria](/wiki/Queen_Victoria "Queen Victoria") in 1842.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-:0-59)^ The status came into force on 29 August 2022.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-:0-59)^{#cite_ref-:0_59-1}  

Governance {#Governance}
------------------------

Main article: [Politics of Gibraltar](/wiki/Politics_of_Gibraltar "Politics of Gibraltar")  
See also: [Disputed status of Gibraltar](/wiki/Disputed_status_of_Gibraltar "Disputed status of Gibraltar") and [Political development in modern Gibraltar](/wiki/Political_development_in_modern_Gibraltar "Political development in modern Gibraltar")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/The_convent_in_Gibraltar_7.jpg/220px-The_convent_in_Gibraltar_7.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_convent_in_Gibraltar_7.jpg) Main Street entrance to the Governor's Residence, [The Convent](/wiki/The_Convent_(Gibraltar) "The Convent (Gibraltar)") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Gibraltar_Parliament_at_dusk.jpg/220px-Gibraltar_Parliament_at_dusk.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gibraltar_Parliament_at_dusk.jpg) [John Mackintosh Square](/wiki/John_Mackintosh_Square "John Mackintosh Square") entrance to the [Gibraltar Parliament](/wiki/Gibraltar_Parliament "Gibraltar Parliament")

Under its current [constitution](/wiki/Gibraltar_Constitution_Order_2006 "Gibraltar Constitution Order 2006"), Gibraltar has almost complete internal [self-governance](/wiki/Self-governance "Self-governance") through a [parliament](/wiki/Gibraltar_Parliament "Gibraltar Parliament")^[\[59\]](#cite_note-publications.parliament.uk-60)^^[\[60\]](#cite_note-61)^^[\[61\]](#cite_note-62)^ elected for a term of up to four years. The [unicameral](/wiki/Unicameralism "Unicameralism") parliament presently consists of 17 elected members, and the [Speaker](/wiki/List_of_Speakers_of_the_Gibraltar_Parliament "List of Speakers of the Gibraltar Parliament") who is not elected but appointed by a resolution of the parliament.^[\[62\]](#cite_note-63)^ The [government](/wiki/Government_of_Gibraltar "Government of Gibraltar") consists of 10 elected members. The head of state is the British monarch [King Charles III](/wiki/King_Charles_III "King Charles III"), who is represented by the [Governor of Gibraltar](/wiki/Governor_of_Gibraltar "Governor of Gibraltar"). The governor enacts day-to-day matters on the advice of the Gibraltar Parliament but is responsible to the British government in respect of defence, foreign policy, internal security and general good governance. Judicial and other appointments are made on behalf of the monarch in consultation with the [head of the elected government](/wiki/Chief_Minister_of_Gibraltar "Chief Minister of Gibraltar").^[\[63\]](#cite_note-64)^^[\[64\]](#cite_note-65)^^[\[65\]](#cite_note-news.bbc.co.uk-66)^{#cite_ref-news.bbc.co.uk_66-0}

The [2011 election](/wiki/2011_Gibraltar_general_election "2011 Gibraltar general election") was contested by the [Gibraltar Social Democrats](/wiki/Gibraltar_Social_Democrats "Gibraltar Social Democrats") (GSD), [Gibraltar Socialist Labour Party](/wiki/Gibraltar_Socialist_Labour_Party "Gibraltar Socialist Labour Party") (GSLP)-[Liberal Party of Gibraltar](/wiki/Liberal_Party_of_Gibraltar "Liberal Party of Gibraltar") (LPG) Alliance and the [Progressive Democratic Party](/wiki/Progressive_Democratic_Party_(Gibraltar) "Progressive Democratic Party (Gibraltar)") (PDP). The PDP was a new party, formed in 2006 and fielded candidates in the 2007 election, but none were elected. The head of government is the [Chief Minister](/wiki/Chief_Minister_of_Gibraltar "Chief Minister of Gibraltar") (as of December 2011^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gibraltar&action=edit)^, [Fabian Picardo](/wiki/Fabian_Picardo "Fabian Picardo")). All local political parties oppose any transfer of sovereignty to Spain, instead supporting [self-determination](/wiki/Self-determination "Self-determination"). The main UK opposition parties also support this policy, and it is British government policy not to engage in talks about the sovereignty of Gibraltar without the consent of the people of Gibraltar.^[\[66\]](#cite_note-67)^{#cite_ref-67}

Gibraltar was part of the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union"), having joined through the [European Communities Act 1972 (UK)](/wiki/European_Communities_Act_1972_(UK) "European Communities Act 1972 (UK)"), which gave effect to the [Treaty of Accession 1972](/wiki/Treaty_of_Accession_1972 "Treaty of Accession 1972"), as a dependent territory of the United Kingdom under what was then article 227(4) of the [Treaty Establishing the European Community](/wiki/Treaty_Establishing_the_European_Community "Treaty Establishing the European Community") covering [special member state territories](/wiki/Gibraltar_and_the_European_Union "Gibraltar and the European Union"), with exemption from some areas such as the [European Union Customs Union](/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union "European Union Customs Union"), [Common Agricultural Policy](/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy "Common Agricultural Policy") and the [Schengen Area](/wiki/Schengen_Area "Schengen Area"). It is the only [British Overseas Territory](/wiki/British_Overseas_Territory "British Overseas Territory") which was part of the European Union. After a 10-year campaign for the right to vote in [European elections](/wiki/Elections_in_the_European_Union "Elections in the European Union"), from 2004 to 2019 the people of Gibraltar participated in elections for the [European Parliament](/wiki/European_Parliament "European Parliament") as part of the [South West England constituency](/wiki/South_West_England_(European_Parliament_constituency) "South West England (European Parliament constituency)").^[\[67\]](#cite_note-68)^ On 23 June 2016 Gibraltar voted along with the United Kingdom in the [EU referendum](/wiki/2016_United_Kingdom_European_Union_membership_referendum "2016 United Kingdom European Union membership referendum"); 96% of its population voted to remain, but the overall United Kingdom result gave a 51.9% majority to leaving the EU.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-69)^ Nevertheless, Spanish Prime Minister [Pedro Sánchez](/wiki/Pedro_S%C3%A1nchez_(politician) "Pedro Sánchez (politician)") stated on 18 October 2018 that the Gibraltar protocol had been "resolved" and that Spain will hold no objection when Gibraltar leaves the EU with Britain.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-70)^^[\[70\]](#cite_note-71)^{#cite_ref-71}

Gibraltar was nominated to be included on the [United Nations list of non-self-governing territories](/wiki/United_Nations_list_of_non-self-governing_territories "United Nations list of non-self-governing territories") by the United Kingdom when the list was created in 1946^[\[71\]](#cite_note-72)^ and has been listed ever since.^[\[72\]](#cite_note-73)^ The government of Gibraltar has actively worked to have Gibraltar removed from the list,^[\[73\]](#cite_note-74)^ and in 2008 the British government declared Gibraltar's continued presence on the list an anachronism.^[\[74\]](#cite_note-75)^{#cite_ref-75}

Gibraltar is not a member of the [Commonwealth of Nations](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of Nations") in its own right and is represented by the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") but was granted Associate Membership of the [Commonwealth Foundation](/wiki/Commonwealth_Foundation "Commonwealth Foundation") in 2004. Gibraltar has competed in the [Commonwealth Games](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games "Commonwealth Games") since 1958.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

### Citizenship {#Citizenship}

Further information: [British passport (Gibraltar)](/wiki/British_passport_(Gibraltar) "British passport (Gibraltar)")

As a result of the [British Nationality Act 1981](/wiki/British_Nationality_Act_1981 "British Nationality Act 1981"), Gibraltarians were made [British Overseas Territories citizens](/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories_citizen "British Overseas Territories citizen") by default, but could apply for registration as a [British citizen](/wiki/British_citizen "British citizen") ("*an entitlement that cannot be refused* ") under section 5 of the Act. Under the subsequent [British Overseas Territories Act 2002](/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories_Act_2002 "British Overseas Territories Act 2002"), all British Overseas Territories citizens became British citizens on 21 May 2002.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^  

International relations {#International_relations}
--------------------------------------------------

Gibraltar is not a sovereign state: its formal international relations are the responsibility of the Government of the United Kingdom. Since Brexit, it is not part of the European Union, but is a participant in the [EU--UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement](/wiki/EU%E2%80%93UK_Trade_and_Cooperation_Agreement "EU–UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

On 31 December 2020, the UK and Spain agreed in principle on a basis for the EU and the UK to negotiate an agreement through which Gibraltar would participate in the [Schengen Area](/wiki/Schengen_Area "Schengen Area"),^[\[21\]](#cite_note-GibStatement-22)^ to avoid a hard border with Spain. The arrangements have not entered into force,^[\[21\]](#cite_note-GibStatement-22)^^[\[55\]](#cite_note-BBC_News-56)^ but both sides aim to keep delays at the border at a minimum in the meantime.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-Ashifa_Kassam-57)^^[\[75\]](#cite_note-76)^^[\[76\]](#cite_note-77)^ As of March 2023^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gibraltar&action=edit)^, talks remain stalled, with Spain insisting that its *[Policía Nacional](/wiki/National_Police_Corps_(Spain) "National Police Corps (Spain)")* control entry into the Schengen area and the UK demanding that the work be done by officers of the European Union agency [Frontex](/wiki/Frontex "Frontex"). All other entry points to the Schengen area are controlled by national authorities, supplemented by Frontex in some places.^[\[22\]](#cite_note-FT240323-23)^{#cite_ref-FT240323_23-1}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

See also: [Rock of Gibraltar](/wiki/Rock_of_Gibraltar "Rock of Gibraltar"), [Bay of Gibraltar](/wiki/Bay_of_Gibraltar "Bay of Gibraltar"), [Strait of Gibraltar](/wiki/Strait_of_Gibraltar "Strait of Gibraltar"), and [Gibraltar Artificial Reef](/wiki/Gibraltar_Artificial_Reef "Gibraltar Artificial Reef")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Rock_of_Gibraltar_from_the_Mediterranean_Steps.jpg/220px-Rock_of_Gibraltar_from_the_Mediterranean_Steps.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rock_of_Gibraltar_from_the_Mediterranean_Steps.jpg) View of the Rock of Gibraltar from the [Mediterranean Steps](/wiki/Mediterranean_Steps "Mediterranean Steps") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Gibraltar2021OSM.png/220px-Gibraltar2021OSM.png)](/wiki/File:Gibraltar2021OSM.png) Enlargeable, detailed map of Gibraltar

Gibraltar's territory covers 6.8 km2 (2.6 sqmi)^[\[3\]](#cite_note-gibraltar.gov.gi-3)^ and shares a 1.2 km (0.75 mi) land border with Spain. The town of [La Línea de la Concepción](/wiki/La_L%C3%ADnea_de_la_Concepci%C3%B3n "La Línea de la Concepción"), a [municipality](/wiki/List_of_municipalities_in_C%C3%A1diz "List of municipalities in Cádiz") of the [province of Cádiz](/wiki/Province_of_C%C3%A1diz "Province of Cádiz"), lies on the Spanish side of the border. The Spanish hinterland forms the [comarca](/wiki/Comarca "Comarca") of [Campo de Gibraltar](/wiki/Campo_de_Gibraltar "Campo de Gibraltar") (literally "Countryside of Gibraltar"). The shoreline measures 12 km (7.5 mi) in length. There are two coasts ("Sides") of Gibraltar: the East Side, which contains the settlements of [Sandy Bay](/wiki/Sandy_Bay,_Gibraltar "Sandy Bay, Gibraltar") and [Catalan Bay](/wiki/Catalan_Bay "Catalan Bay"); and the [Westside](/wiki/Westside_(Gibraltar) "Westside (Gibraltar)"), where the vast majority of the population lives. Gibraltar has no administrative divisions but is divided into seven [Major Residential Areas](/wiki/Gibraltar_Major_Residential_Areas "Gibraltar Major Residential Areas").{#cite_ref-gibraltar.gov.gi_3-5}

Having negligible [natural resources](/wiki/Natural_resource "Natural resource") and few natural [freshwater](/wiki/Freshwater "Freshwater") resources, limited to natural wells in the north, until recently Gibraltar used large concrete or natural rock [water catchments](/wiki/Drainage_basin "Drainage basin") to collect rainwater. Fresh water from the boreholes is nowadays supplemented by two [desalination](/wiki/Desalination "Desalination") plants: a [reverse osmosis](/wiki/Reverse_osmosis "Reverse osmosis") plant, constructed in a tunnel within the rock, and a [multi-stage flash distillation](/wiki/Multi-stage_flash_distillation "Multi-stage flash distillation") plant at North Mole.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-78)^{#cite_ref-78}

Gibraltar's terrain consists of the 426 m-high (1,398 ft) [Rock of Gibraltar](/wiki/Rock_of_Gibraltar "Rock of Gibraltar")^[\[78\]](#cite_note-79)^ made of [Jurassic](/wiki/Jurassic "Jurassic") [limestone](/wiki/Limestone "Limestone"), and the narrow coastal lowland surrounding it. It contains many tunnelled roads, most of which are still operated by the military and closed to the general public.{#cite_ref-79}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/View_from_top_of_Gib_rock.jpg/1000px-View_from_top_of_Gib_rock.jpg)](/wiki/File:View_from_top_of_Gib_rock.jpg "Morocco (top far left across Strait); Spain: Algeciras (top centre across Bay of Gibraltar) and La Linea (right); Gibraltar cruise port and airport runway (right foreground); from the Rock")  
[](/wiki/File:View_from_top_of_Gib_rock.jpg "File:View from top of Gib rock.jpg") Morocco (top far left across Strait); Spain: Algeciras (top centre across Bay of Gibraltar) and La Linea (right); Gibraltar cruise port and airport runway (right foreground); from the Rock  

### Climate {#Climate}

Main article: [Climate of Gibraltar](/wiki/Climate_of_Gibraltar "Climate of Gibraltar")

Gibraltar has a [Mediterranean climate](/wiki/Mediterranean_climate "Mediterranean climate") ([Köppen climate classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification") *Csa* ),^[\[79\]](#cite_note-80)^^[\[80\]](#cite_note-81)^ with mild, rainy winters and summers that are very warm to hot and humid, but with very little rainfall. As is the case for nearby [Algeciras](/wiki/Algeciras "Algeciras") and [Tarifa](/wiki/Tarifa "Tarifa"), summers are significantly cooler and annual temperature more constant than other cities on the southern coast of the Iberian peninsula because of its position on the Strait of Gibraltar. Rain occurs mainly in winter, with summer being generally dry. Its average annual temperature is 21.7 °C (71.1 °F) as a daily high and 15.8 °C (60.4 °F) as the overnight low. In the coldest month, January, the high temperature averages 16.3 °C (61.3 °F) and the overnight low averages 11.2 °C (52.2 °F) and the average sea temperature is 16 °C (61 °F). In the warmest month, August, the daily high temperature averages 28.4 °C (83.1 °F), the overnight low averages 21.2 °C (70.2 °F), and the average sea temperature is 22 °C (72 °F).^[\[81\]](#cite_note-DWD-82)^ ^[\[82\]](#cite_note-weather2travel-83)^{#cite_ref-weather2travel_83-0}

### Flora and fauna {#Flora_and_fauna}

See also: [List of mammals of Gibraltar](/wiki/List_of_mammals_of_Gibraltar "List of mammals of Gibraltar"), [List of birds of Gibraltar](/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Gibraltar "List of birds of Gibraltar"), and [List of amphibians and reptiles of Gibraltar](/wiki/List_of_amphibians_and_reptiles_of_Gibraltar "List of amphibians and reptiles of Gibraltar")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Iberis_gibraltarica.JPG/220px-Iberis_gibraltarica.JPG)](/wiki/File:Iberis_gibraltarica.JPG) [Gibraltar candytuft](/wiki/Iberis_gibraltarica "Iberis gibraltarica") growing at the [Gibraltar Botanic Gardens](/wiki/Gibraltar_Botanic_Gardens "Gibraltar Botanic Gardens") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Common_dolphin_taken_by_Graham_Hesketh_of_Dolphin_Safari.png/220px-Common_dolphin_taken_by_Graham_Hesketh_of_Dolphin_Safari.png)](/wiki/File:Common_dolphin_taken_by_Graham_Hesketh_of_Dolphin_Safari.png) A [common dolphin](/wiki/Common_dolphin "Common dolphin") in the [Bay of Gibraltar](/wiki/Bay_of_Gibraltar "Bay of Gibraltar")

Over 500 different species of [flowering plants](/wiki/Flowering_plant "Flowering plant") grow on the Rock. Gibraltar is the only place in Europe where the *Gibraltar candytuft* (*[Iberis gibraltarica](/wiki/Iberis_gibraltarica "Iberis gibraltarica")* ) is found growing in the wild; the plant is otherwise native to North Africa. It is the symbol of the [Upper Rock nature reserve](/wiki/Rock_of_Gibraltar#Upper_Rock_Nature_Reserve "Rock of Gibraltar"). [Olive](/wiki/Olive "Olive") and [pine](/wiki/Pine "Pine") trees are among the most common of those growing around the Rock.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

Most of the Rock's upper area is covered by a [nature reserve](/wiki/Nature_reserve "Nature reserve") which is home to around 230 [Barbary macaques](/wiki/Gibraltar_Barbary_macaques "Gibraltar Barbary macaques"), the famous "apes" of Gibraltar, which are actually [monkeys](/wiki/Monkey "Monkey"). These are the only wild apes or monkeys found in Europe.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-91)^ This species, known scientifically as *[Macaca sylvanus](/wiki/Macaca_sylvanus "Macaca sylvanus")* , is listed as endangered by the [IUCN Red List](/wiki/IUCN_Red_List "IUCN Red List") and is declining. Three-quarters of the world population live in the [Middle Atlas](/wiki/Middle_Atlas "Middle Atlas") mountains of [Morocco](/wiki/Morocco "Morocco"). Recent genetic studies and historical documents point to their presence on the Rock before British control, having possibly been introduced during the Islamic period. A superstition analogous to that of the [ravens](/wiki/Raven "Raven") at the [Tower of London](/wiki/Tower_of_London "Tower of London") states that if the apes ever leave, so will the British. In 1944, [British Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom "Prime Minister of the United Kingdom") [Winston Churchill](/wiki/Winston_Churchill "Winston Churchill") was so concerned about the dwindling population of apes that he sent a message to the [Colonial Secretary](/wiki/Chief_Secretary_(British_Empire) "Chief Secretary (British Empire)") requesting that something be done about the situation.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-92)^{#cite_ref-92}

Other mammals found in Gibraltar include rabbits, foxes and bats. Dolphins and whales are frequently seen in the [Bay of Gibraltar](/wiki/Bay_of_Gibraltar "Bay of Gibraltar"). Migrating birds are very common and Gibraltar is home to the only [Barbary partridges](/wiki/Barbary_partridge "Barbary partridge") found on the European continent.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

In 1991, Graham Watson, Gibraltar's [MEP](/wiki/Member_of_the_European_Parliament "Member of the European Parliament"), highlighted [conservationists](/wiki/Conservationism "Conservationism")' fears that [urban development](/wiki/Urban_development "Urban development"), tourism and [invasive plant species](/wiki/Invasive_plant_species "Invasive plant species") were threatening Gibraltar's own plants as well as birds and [bat species](/wiki/Bat_species "Bat species").^[\[89\]](#cite_note-93)^{#cite_ref-93}  

### Environment {#Environment}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/RockofGibraltar.jpg/220px-RockofGibraltar.jpg)](/wiki/File:RockofGibraltar.jpg) The Rock of Gibraltar (2010)

In May 2016, a report by the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World Health Organization") showed that Gibraltar had the worst air quality in any British territory. The report concentrated on [PM10](/wiki/PM10 "PM10") and [PM2.5](/wiki/PM2.5 "PM2.5") pollutants in the air.^[\[90\]](#cite_note-94)^{#cite_ref-94}  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

Main article: [Economy of Gibraltar](/wiki/Economy_of_Gibraltar "Economy of Gibraltar")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Barbary_macaque_and_tourists.jpg/170px-Barbary_macaque_and_tourists.jpg)](/wiki/File:Barbary_macaque_and_tourists.jpg) The semi-wild [Barbary macaques](/wiki/Gibraltar_Barbary_macaques "Gibraltar Barbary macaques") are an integral feature in [Gibraltar's tourism](/wiki/Tourism_in_Gibraltar "Tourism in Gibraltar").

Gibraltar's economy is dominated by four main sectors: [financial services](/wiki/Offshore_financial_centre "Offshore financial centre"), [online gambling](/wiki/Online_gambling "Online gambling"), shipping, and tourism, which includes duty-free retail sales to visitors.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-95)^ The [British military](/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(United_Kingdom) "Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)") traditionally dominated [Gibraltar's economy](/wiki/Economy_of_Gibraltar "Economy of Gibraltar"), with the [naval dockyard](/wiki/Naval_dockyard "Naval dockyard") providing the bulk of economic activity. This, however, has diminished over the last 20 years and is estimated to account for only seven per cent of the local economy, compared to over 60 per cent in 1984. The territory also has a small manufacturing sector, representing a bit less than two per cent of the economy.{#cite_ref-95}

Gibraltar's [labour market](/wiki/Labour_market "Labour market") employs around thirty thousand workers, 80% in the private sector and 20% in the public sector. The unemployment rate is extremely low, at around one per cent.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

More than half (53 per cent) of the labour force are resident in Spain or are non Gibraltarians. According to the Government of Gibraltar's statistics, around 45 per cent of the total employee jobs, and 58% of the private sector jobs, are held by frontier workers (employees who are normally resident in Spain but are employed in Gibraltar). Around 63 per cent of the frontier workers are Spanish nationals. More than half (55 per cent) of the private sector employee jobs are held by persons who are not Gibraltarians or Other British nationalities. The public sector, on the other hand, employs mainly Gibraltarians and other British (90 per cent).^[\[92\]](#cite_note-96)^ As a consequence, according to [Fabian Picardo](/wiki/Fabian_Picardo "Fabian Picardo"), Chief Minister of Gibraltar, during Brexit negotiations, a frontier which lacked the necessary fluidity for people to be able to access their places of work would put directly at risk nearly half of the jobs of the Gibraltar workforce.^[\[93\]](#cite_note-97)^^[\[94\]](#cite_note-98)^{#cite_ref-98}

In the early 2000s, many [bookmakers](/wiki/Bookmaker "Bookmaker") and online gaming operators moved to Gibraltar to benefit from operating in a regulated jurisdiction with a favourable [corporate tax](/wiki/Corporate_tax "Corporate tax") regime. This corporate tax regime for non-resident controlled companies was phased out by January 2011 and replaced by a still favourable fixed corporate tax rate of ten per cent.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-99)^{#cite_ref-99}

Tourism is also a significant industry. Gibraltar is a popular port for cruise ships and attracts day visitors from resorts in Spain. The Rock is a popular tourist attraction, particularly among British tourists and residents in the southern coast of Spain. It is also a popular shopping destination, and all goods and services are [VAT](/wiki/Value_added_tax "Value added tax") free, but may be subject to Gibraltar taxes. Many of the large British high street chains have branches or franchises in Gibraltar including [Morrisons](/wiki/Morrisons "Morrisons"), [Marks \& Spencer](/wiki/Marks_%26_Spencer "Marks & Spencer") and [Mothercare](/wiki/Mothercare "Mothercare"). Branches and franchises of international retailers such as [Tommy Hilfiger](/wiki/Tommy_Hilfiger "Tommy Hilfiger") and [Sunglass Hut](/wiki/Sunglass_Hut_International "Sunglass Hut International") are also present in Gibraltar, as is the Spanish clothing company [Mango](/wiki/Mango_(clothing) "Mango (clothing)").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Queensway_Quay_in_Gibraltar.jpg/220px-Queensway_Quay_in_Gibraltar.jpg)](/wiki/File:Queensway_Quay_in_Gibraltar.jpg) [Queensway Quay Marina](/wiki/Queensway_Quay_Marina "Queensway Quay Marina"), a residential district

A number of [British and international banks](/wiki/List_of_banks_in_Gibraltar "List of banks in Gibraltar") have operations based in Gibraltar. [Jyske Bank](/wiki/Jyske_Bank "Jyske Bank") claims to be the oldest bank in the country, based on Jyske's acquisition in 1987 of [Banco Galliano](/wiki/Banco_Galliano "Banco Galliano"), which began operations in Gibraltar in 1855. An ancestor of [Barclays](/wiki/Barclays "Barclays"), the [Anglo-Egyptian Bank](/wiki/Anglo-Egyptian_Bank "Anglo-Egyptian Bank"), entered in 1888, and Credit Foncier (now [Crédit Agricole](/wiki/Cr%C3%A9dit_Agricole "Crédit Agricole")) entered in 1920.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

There is some manufacturing activity, representing around 2% of the total employment. One company (Bassadone Automotive Group) supplies ambulances and other project vehicles converted locally from [SUV](/wiki/SUV "SUV") vehicles to the United Nations and other agencies, employing some 320 staff across its range of activities.^[\[96\]](#cite_note-100)^{#cite_ref-100}

In 1967, Gibraltar enacted the Companies (Taxation and Concessions) Ordinance (now an Act), which provided for special tax treatment for international business.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-101)^ This was one of the factors leading to the growth of professional services such as [private banking](/wiki/Private_banking "Private banking") and captive insurance management. Gibraltar has several attractive attributes as a [financial centre](/wiki/Financial_centre "Financial centre"), including a [common law](/wiki/Common_law "Common law") [legal system](/wiki/Law_of_Gibraltar "Law of Gibraltar") and access to the EU single market in financial services. Gibraltar is considered a high class jurisdiction and is listed on the "white list" by the [Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)](/wiki/OECD "OECD") due to its highly regulated financial and e-gaming sectors, sharing the same status as the UK, USA and Germany.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-Kunar_et_al-102)^ It is internationally collaborative, including in the exchange of information on tax matters.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-Kunar_et_al-102)^{#cite_ref-Kunar_et_al_102-1}

The [Gibraltar Stock Exchange](/wiki/Gibraltar_Stock_Exchange "Gibraltar Stock Exchange") was established in 2014.

In January 2018, Gibraltar introduced a regulatory framework for Distributed Ledger Technology, with the aim of pursuing a "more flexible, adaptive approach... in the case of novel business activities, products, and business models".^[\[99\]](#cite_note-103)^^[\[100\]](#cite_note-104)^ The Financial Services Commission (FSC),^[\[101\]](#cite_note-105)^ which was established by an ordinance in 1989 (now an Act) that took effect in 1991, regulates the finance sector.^[\[102\]](#cite_note-106)^ In 1997, the Department of Trade and Industry established its Gibraltar Finance Centre (GFC) Division to facilitate the development the [financial sector development](/wiki/Financial_sector_development "Financial sector development"). As of 2012^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gibraltar&action=edit)^, Gibraltar has 0.103 [Big Four](/wiki/Big_Four_(audit_firms) "Big Four (audit firms)") accounting firm offices per 1,000 population, the second highest in the world after the [British Virgin Islands](/wiki/British_Virgin_Islands "British Virgin Islands"), and 0.6 banks per 1,000 people, the fifth most banks per capita in the world.^[\[103\]](#cite_note-107)^ As of 2017^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gibraltar&action=edit)^, there is [very significant uncertainty](/wiki/Effect_of_Brexit_on_Gibraltar "Effect of Brexit on Gibraltar") on continuing access to the EU single market after the forthcoming [Brexit](/wiki/Brexit "Brexit").^[\[104\]](#cite_note-108)^{#cite_ref-108}

The currency of Gibraltar is the [Gibraltar pound](/wiki/Gibraltar_pound "Gibraltar pound"), issued by the [Government of Gibraltar](/wiki/Government_of_Gibraltar "Government of Gibraltar") under the terms of the 1934 *Currency Notes Act* . These banknotes are [legal tender](/wiki/Legal_tender "Legal tender") in Gibraltar alongside Bank of England banknotes.^[\[105\]](#cite_note-109)^^[\[106\]](#cite_note-currnotesact-110)^ In a [currency board](/wiki/Currency_board "Currency board") arrangement, these notes are issued against reserves of [sterling](/wiki/Pound_sterling "Pound sterling").^[\[106\]](#cite_note-currnotesact-110)^^[\[107\]](#cite_note-111)^^[\[108\]](#cite_note-112)^ Clearing and settlement of funds is conducted in sterling.^[\[109\]](#cite_note-113)^ [Coins](/wiki/Coins_of_the_Gibraltar_pound "Coins of the Gibraltar pound") in circulation follow British denominations but have separate designs. Unofficially, most retail outlets in Gibraltar accept the [euro](/wiki/Euro "Euro"), though some [payphones](/wiki/Payphone "Payphone") and the [Royal Gibraltar Post Office](/wiki/Royal_Gibraltar_Post_Office "Royal Gibraltar Post Office"), along with all other government offices, do not.^[\[110\]](#cite_note-114)^{#cite_ref-114}  

Demographics {#Demographics}
----------------------------

Main article: [Demographics of Gibraltar](/wiki/Demographics_of_Gibraltar "Demographics of Gibraltar")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Cathedral_of_St._Mary_the_Crowned%2C_Gibraltar.jpg/220px-Cathedral_of_St._Mary_the_Crowned%2C_Gibraltar.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cathedral_of_St._Mary_the_Crowned,_Gibraltar.jpg) The Roman Catholic [Cathedral of St. Mary the Crowned](/wiki/Cathedral_of_St._Mary_the_Crowned "Cathedral of St. Mary the Crowned") was built in 1462 and is the territory's oldest Catholic church. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Gibraltar_Hindu_Temple_altar.JPG/220px-Gibraltar_Hindu_Temple_altar.JPG)](/wiki/File:Gibraltar_Hindu_Temple_altar.JPG) The [Gibraltar Hindu Temple](/wiki/Gibraltar_Hindu_Temple "Gibraltar Hindu Temple") opened in 2000. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Mosque_of_Gibraltar.jpg/220px-Mosque_of_Gibraltar.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mosque_of_Gibraltar.jpg) The [Ibrahim-al-Ibrahim Mosque](/wiki/Ibrahim-al-Ibrahim_Mosque "Ibrahim-al-Ibrahim Mosque") was a gift from [King Fahd](/wiki/Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia "Fahd of Saudi Arabia") of [Saudi Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia "Saudi Arabia").

Gibraltar is one of the most densely populated territories in the world, with a usually-resident population in 2012 of 32,194^[\[111\]](#cite_note-115)^ equivalent to approximately 4,959/km^2^ (12,840/sq mi). The growing demand for space is being increasingly met by [land reclamation](/wiki/Land_reclamation "Land reclamation"); reclaimed land makes up approximately one-tenth of the territory's total area, but houses over 40% of its population (2012 Census).{#cite_ref-115}  

### Ethnic groups {#Ethnic_groups}

See also: [Gibraltarian people](/wiki/Gibraltarian_people "Gibraltarian people")

According to the 2012 Gibraltar census, 25,444 people (79.0%) were eligible for "Gibraltarian" status. Of the rest, 4249 (13.2%) were "other British", 675 (2.1%) were Spanish, 522 (1.6%) were Moroccan and 785 (2.4%) had other EU nationalities. There were 519 people (1.6%) with other nationalities.^[\[112\]](#cite_note-116)^{#cite_ref-116}

### Language {#Language}

Main article: [Languages of Gibraltar](/wiki/Languages_of_Gibraltar "Languages of Gibraltar")

The [official language](/wiki/Official_language "Official language") of Gibraltar is English and is used by the government and in schools. Most locals are [bilingual](/wiki/Multilingualism "Multilingualism"), also speaking Spanish. However, because of the varied mix of ethnic groups which reside there, other languages are also spoken on the Rock. [Berber](/wiki/Berber_languages "Berber languages") and [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic "Arabic") are spoken by the [Moroccan](/wiki/Morocco "Morocco") community, as are [Hindi](/wiki/Hindi "Hindi") and [Sindhi](/wiki/Sindhi_language "Sindhi language") by the Indian community. [Maltese](/wiki/Maltese_language "Maltese language") is spoken by some families of [Maltese descent](/wiki/History_of_the_Maltese_in_Gibraltar "History of the Maltese in Gibraltar").^[\[114\]](#cite_note-Archer2013-118)^{#cite_ref-Archer2013_118-0}

Gibraltarians often converse in *[Llanito](/wiki/Llanito "Llanito")* (
pronounced [\[ʎaˈnito\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish "Help:IPA/Spanish")), a [vernacular](/wiki/Vernacular "Vernacular") unique to Gibraltar. It is based on [Andalusian Spanish](/wiki/Andalusian_Spanish "Andalusian Spanish") with a strong mixture of [British English](/wiki/British_English "British English") and elements from languages such as Maltese, [Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language"), [Genoese Italian](/wiki/Genoese_dialect "Genoese dialect") and [Haketia](/wiki/Haketia "Haketia") (a [Judaeo-Spanish](/wiki/Judaeo-Spanish "Judaeo-Spanish") dialect). Llanito also often involves [code-switching](/wiki/Code-switching "Code-switching") to English and Spanish.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

The English language is becoming increasingly dominant in Gibraltar, with the younger generation speaking little or no Llanito despite learning Spanish in school.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-119)^{#cite_ref-119}

Gibraltarians often call themselves *Llanitos* .^[\[116\]](#cite_note-Kellermann2001-120)^{#cite_ref-Kellermann2001_120-0}

According to the 2012 census, approximately 72.1% of Gibraltarians are [Roman Catholics](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church").^[\[117\]](#cite_note-auto-121)^ The 16th-century [Saint Mary the Crowned](/wiki/Cathedral_of_Saint_Mary_the_Crowned "Cathedral of Saint Mary the Crowned") is the cathedral church of the [Roman Catholic Diocese of Gibraltar](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Diocese_of_Gibraltar "Roman Catholic Diocese of Gibraltar"), and also the oldest Catholic church in the territory. Other Christian denominations include the [Church of England](/wiki/Church_of_England "Church of England") (7.7%), whose [Cathedral of the Holy Trinity](/wiki/Cathedral_of_the_Holy_Trinity,_Gibraltar "Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, Gibraltar") is the cathedral of the Anglican [Bishop of Gibraltar in Europe](/wiki/Bishop_of_Gibraltar_in_Europe "Bishop of Gibraltar in Europe"); the [Gibraltar Methodist Church](/wiki/Gibraltar_Methodist_Church "Gibraltar Methodist Church"),^[\[118\]](#cite_note-122)^ [Church of Scotland](/wiki/Church_of_Scotland "Church of Scotland"), various [Pentecostal](/wiki/Pentecostal "Pentecostal") and independent churches mostly influenced by the [House Church](/wiki/House_Church "House Church") and [Charismatic movements](/wiki/Charismatic_movement "Charismatic movement"), as well as a [Plymouth Brethren](/wiki/Plymouth_Brethren "Plymouth Brethren") congregation. Several of these congregations are represented by the Gibraltar Evangelical Alliance.{#cite_ref-122}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Cathedral_of_the_Holy_Trinity.jpg/220px-Cathedral_of_the_Holy_Trinity.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cathedral_of_the_Holy_Trinity.jpg) [Cathedral of the Holy Trinity](/wiki/Cathedral_of_the_Holy_Trinity,_Gibraltar "Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, Gibraltar")

There is also a [ward](/wiki/Ward_(LDS_Church) "Ward (LDS Church)") of [the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints](/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints "The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints"), and two congregations of [Jehovah's Witnesses](/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses "Jehovah's Witnesses").

7.1% advised that they have no religion.

The third religion in size is [Islam](/wiki/Islam "Islam") (3.6% of the population). There is also an established [Hindu](/wiki/Hindu "Hindu") population (2%), members of the [Baháʼí Faith](/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith "Baháʼí Faith") and a long-established [Jewish community](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Gibraltar "History of the Jews in Gibraltar"), which, at 763 persons, accounts for 2.4% of the population.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-auto-121)^ There are four functioning [Orthodox synagogues in Gibraltar](/wiki/Synagogues_of_Gibraltar "Synagogues of Gibraltar") and several kosher establishments.{#cite_ref-auto_121-1}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

Main article: [Education in Gibraltar](/wiki/Education_in_Gibraltar "Education in Gibraltar")

[Education in Gibraltar](/wiki/Education_in_Gibraltar "Education in Gibraltar") generally follows the [English model](/wiki/Education_in_England "Education in England"), operating within a [three tier system](/wiki/Three-tier_education "Three-tier education"). Schools in Gibraltar use the [Key Stage](/wiki/Key_Stage "Key Stage") modular approach to teach the [National Curriculum](/wiki/National_Curriculum_(England,_Wales_and_Northern_Ireland) "National Curriculum (England, Wales and Northern Ireland)"). Gibraltar has 15 [state schools](/wiki/State_school "State school"), two private schools and a college of further education, [Gibraltar College](/wiki/Gibraltar_College "Gibraltar College"). Government secondary schools are [Bayside Comprehensive School](/wiki/Bayside_Comprehensive_School_(Gibraltar) "Bayside Comprehensive School (Gibraltar)") and [Westside School](/wiki/Westside_School_(Gibraltar) "Westside School (Gibraltar)"), both of which are [coeducational](/wiki/Mixed-sex_education "Mixed-sex education"), and Prior Park School Gibraltar is an independent co-ed secondary school.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-123)^{#cite_ref-123}

On 31 March 2015, the government of Gibraltar announced the adoption of the University of Gibraltar Act and the [University of Gibraltar](/wiki/University_of_Gibraltar "University of Gibraltar") opened in September 2015.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-124)^^[\[121\]](#cite_note-125)^ Previously, there were no facilities in Gibraltar for full-time higher education, and consequently, all Gibraltarian students studied elsewhere at [degree](/wiki/Academic_degree "Academic degree") level or its equivalent and also for certain non-degree courses.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-126)^{#cite_ref-126}  

Health care {#Health_care}
--------------------------

All Gibraltarians are entitled to health care in public [wards](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ward "wikt:ward") and clinics at [St Bernard's Hospital](/wiki/St_Bernard%27s_Hospital "St Bernard's Hospital") and [primary health care](/wiki/Primary_health_care "Primary health care") centre. All other British citizens are also entitled to free-of-charge treatment on the Rock on presentation of a valid [British passport](/wiki/British_passport "British passport") during stays of up to 30 days. [Dental treatment](/wiki/Dental_surgery "Dental surgery") and [prescribed medicines](/wiki/Prescription_drug "Prescription drug") are free of charge for Gibraltarian students, [pensioners](/wiki/Pensioner "Pensioner") and disabled individuals.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-127)^{#cite_ref-127}

The [Gibraltar Health Authority](/wiki/Gibraltar_Health_Authority "Gibraltar Health Authority"), established under the Medical (Gibraltar Health Authority) Act of 1987^[\[124\]](#cite_note-128)^ is funded through the Gibraltar Group Practice Medical Scheme. It employs around 900 people, handling 37,000 [A\&E](/wiki/Accident_and_emergency "Accident and emergency") attendances, 40,000 outpatient appointments, and 90,000 [GP](/wiki/General_practitioner "General practitioner") visits a year. Some specialist care is provided by visiting consultants and in UK and Spanish hospitals. First-line medical and nursing services are provided at the Primary Care Centre, which has 16 GPs, with more specialised services available at [St Bernard's Hospital](/wiki/St_Bernard%27s_Hospital "St Bernard's Hospital"), a 210-bed civilian hospital opened in 2005. Psychiatric care is provided by Ocean Views.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-128}

As of 2012 the authority was responsible for the health of some 27,000 individuals. The GHA and Social Welfare System are closely based upon their British counterparts, namely the [National Health Service](/wiki/National_Health_Service "National Health Service").^[\[125\]](#cite_note-Kellermann2002-129)^ As of 2003 the organisation was funded through roughly [£](/wiki/Gibraltar_pound "Gibraltar pound")19 million ([$](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar")27 million) of [social insurance](/wiki/Social_insurance "Social insurance") stamp contributions through the Gibraltar Group Practice Medical Scheme.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-Europe_Review-130)^{#cite_ref-Europe_Review_130-0}

In September 2014 [Egton Medical Information Systems](/wiki/Egton_Medical_Information_Systems "Egton Medical Information Systems") won a contract, worth up to £11.25m over 10 years, to deliver an [electronic patient record](/wiki/Electronic_patient_record "Electronic patient record") for the health service of Gibraltar including a [patient administration system](/wiki/Patient_administration_system "Patient administration system"), an emergency department system, e-prescribing and other software from Ascribe, which Emis bought in September 2013.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-131)^ The A\&E unit at St Bernard's Hospital went live on 24 June 2015 using Emis' Symphony and it is planned that primary and community services and the acute hospital will start to use the Ascribe CaMIS patient administration system.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-132)^{#cite_ref-132}

A Community Mental Health Team was established in 2017, and in 2018 the Gibraltar Health Authority School of Health Studies introduced a Mental Health Nursing degree to tackle difficulties in recruiting mental health nurses.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-133)^{#cite_ref-133}  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

Main article: [Culture of Gibraltar](/wiki/Culture_of_Gibraltar "Culture of Gibraltar")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Gibraltar_Tercentenary_flag_display.jpg/220px-Gibraltar_Tercentenary_flag_display.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gibraltar_Tercentenary_flag_display.jpg) [Tercentenary](/wiki/Tercentenary "Tercentenary") celebrations in Gibraltar

The [culture of Gibraltar](/wiki/Culture_of_Gibraltar "Culture of Gibraltar") reflects Gibraltarians' diverse origins. While there are Spanish (mostly from nearby [Andalusia](/wiki/Andalusia "Andalusia")) and British influences, the ethnic origins of most Gibraltarians are not confined to these ethnicities. Other ethnicities include [Genoese](/wiki/Genoa "Genoa"), [Maltese](/wiki/Maltese_people "Maltese people"), [Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_people "Portuguese people"), and [German](/wiki/Germany "Germany"). A few other Gibraltar residents are [Jewish of Sephardic](/wiki/Sephardi_Jews "Sephardi Jews") origin, [Moroccan](/wiki/Morocco "Morocco"), or [Indians](/wiki/Non-resident_Indian_and_person_of_Indian_origin "Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin"). British influence remains strong, with English being the language of government, commerce, education and the media.

[Gibraltar's first sovereignty referendum](/wiki/1967_Gibraltar_sovereignty_referendum "1967 Gibraltar sovereignty referendum") is celebrated annually on [Gibraltar National Day](/wiki/Gibraltar_National_Day "Gibraltar National Day") (10 September). It is a public holiday, during which most Gibraltarians dress in their [national colours](/wiki/National_colours "National colours") of red and white. Until 2016, the tradition had been to also release 30,000 similarly coloured balloons, which represented the people of Gibraltar. However, this tradition has now been ended because of the threat that it poses to wildlife, particularly marine.^[\[130\]](#cite_note-134)^ The 300th anniversary of [Gibraltar's capture](/wiki/Capture_of_Gibraltar "Capture of Gibraltar") was celebrated in 2004 on Tercentenary Day (4 August), when in recognition of and with thanks for its long association with Gibraltar, the [Royal Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy") was given the [Freedom of the City of Gibraltar](/w/index.php?title=Freedom_of_the_City_of_Gibraltar&action=edit&redlink=1 "Freedom of the City of Gibraltar (page does not exist)") and a human chain of Gibraltarians dressed in red, white and blue, linked hands to encircle the Rock. On 4 June 2012, the [Gibraltar Diamond Jubilee Flotilla](/wiki/Gibraltar_Diamond_Jubilee_Flotilla "Gibraltar Diamond Jubilee Flotilla"), inspired by the [Thames Diamond Jubilee Pageant](/wiki/Thames_Diamond_Jubilee_Pageant "Thames Diamond Jubilee Pageant"), celebrated sixty years of the [Queen](/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II "Queen Elizabeth II")'s reign.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-135)^{#cite_ref-135}

The [Gibraltar Broadcasting Corporation](/wiki/Gibraltar_Broadcasting_Corporation "Gibraltar Broadcasting Corporation") operates a television and radio station on UHF, VHF and medium-wave. The radio service is also internet-streamed. Special events and the daily news bulletin are streamed in video. The other local radio service is operated by the [British Forces Broadcasting Service](/wiki/British_Forces_Broadcasting_Service "British Forces Broadcasting Service") which also provides a limited cable television network to HM Forces. The largest and most frequently published newspaper is the *[Gibraltar Chronicle](/wiki/Gibraltar_Chronicle "Gibraltar Chronicle")* , Gibraltar's oldest established daily newspaper and the world's second-oldest English language newspaper to have been in print continuously^[\[132\]](#cite_note-136)^ with daily editions six days a week. *[Panorama](/wiki/Panorama_(Gibraltar) "Panorama (Gibraltar)")* is published on weekdays, and *7 Days* , *The New People* , and *Gibsport* are weekly.{#cite_ref-136}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Gibraltar_National_Day_027_%289719742224%29_%282%29.jpg/220px-Gibraltar_National_Day_027_%289719742224%29_%282%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gibraltar_National_Day_027_(9719742224)_(2).jpg) Thousands of [Gibraltarians](/wiki/Gibraltarian_people "Gibraltarian people") dress in their national colours of red and white during the 2013 [Gibraltar National Day](/wiki/Gibraltar_National_Day "Gibraltar National Day") celebrations.

Native Gibraltarians have produced some literature of note. The first in fiction was probably [Héctor Licudi](/wiki/H%C3%A9ctor_Licudi "Héctor Licudi")'s 1929 novel *Barbarita* , written in Spanish,^[\[133\]](#cite_note-137)^ chronicling the largely autobiographical adventures of a young Gibraltarian man. Throughout the 1940s and 1950s, several anthologies of poetry were published by [Leopoldo Sanguinetti](/wiki/Leopoldo_Sanguinetti "Leopoldo Sanguinetti"), [Albert Joseph Patron](/w/index.php?title=Albert_Joseph_Patron&action=edit&redlink=1 "Albert Joseph Patron (page does not exist)") and [Alberto Pizzarello](/wiki/Alberto_Pizzarello "Alberto Pizzarello"). The 1960s were largely dominated by the theatrical works of [Elio Cruz](/wiki/Elio_Cruz "Elio Cruz") and his two highly acclaimed Spanish language plays *La Lola se va pá Londre* and *Connie con cama camera en el comedor* .^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ In the 1990s, the Gibraltarian [man-of-letters](/wiki/Intellectual "Intellectual") [Mario Arroyo](/wiki/Mario_Arroyo "Mario Arroyo") published *Profiles* (1994), a series of bilingual meditations on love, loneliness and death. [Trino Cruz](/wiki/Trino_Cruz "Trino Cruz") is a bilingual poet originally writing English but now mainly in Spanish, who also translates [Maghreb](/wiki/Maghreb "Maghreb") poetry.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-138)^^[\[135\]](#cite_note-ElPais-139)^^[\[136\]](#cite_note-Téllez2013-140)^ Of late there have been works by the essayist [Mary Chiappe](/wiki/Mary_Chiappe "Mary Chiappe"), such as her volume of essays *Cabbages and Kings* (2006) and by [M. G. Sanchez](/wiki/M._G._Sanchez "M. G. Sanchez"), author of the books *Rock Black: Ten Gibraltarian Stories* (2008) and *Diary of a Victorian Colonial* (2009). Mary Chiappe and [Sam Benady](/wiki/Sam_Benady "Sam Benady") have also published a series of detective books centred on the character of the nineteenth-century Gibraltarian sleuth Bresciano.{#cite_ref-Téllez2013_140-0}

Musicians from Gibraltar include [Charles Ramirez](/wiki/Charles_Ramirez "Charles Ramirez"), the first guitarist invited to play with the [Royal College of Music](/wiki/Royal_College_of_Music "Royal College of Music") Orchestra,^[\[137\]](#cite_note-141)^ successful rock bands like [Breed 77](/wiki/Breed_77 "Breed 77"), [Melon Diesel](/wiki/Melon_Diesel "Melon Diesel") and [Taxi](/wiki/Taxi_(Gibraltar_band) "Taxi (Gibraltar band)"), while Gibraltarian bassist Glen Diani played for Irish/British [nu metal](/wiki/Nu_metal "Nu metal") group [One Minute Silence](/wiki/One_Minute_Silence "One Minute Silence"). [Albert Hammond](/wiki/Albert_Hammond "Albert Hammond") had top 10 hits in the UK and US and has written many songs for international artists such as [Whitney Houston](/wiki/Whitney_Houston "Whitney Houston"), [Tina Turner](/wiki/Tina_Turner "Tina Turner") and [Julio Iglesias](/wiki/Julio_Iglesias "Julio Iglesias").^[\[138\]](#cite_note-142)^{#cite_ref-142}

[Gibraltarian cuisine](/wiki/Gibraltarian_cuisine "Gibraltarian cuisine") is the result of a long relationship between the Andalusian Spaniards and the British, as well as the many foreigners who made Gibraltar their home over the past three centuries. The culinary influences include those from Malta, Genoa, Portugal, Andalusia and Britain. This marriage of tastes has given Gibraltar an eclectic mix of Mediterranean and British cuisine, such as [calentita](/wiki/Calentita "Calentita"), a baked bread-like dish made with [chickpea flour](/wiki/Gram_flour "Gram flour"), water, olive oil, salt and pepper.
