Sport {#Sport}
--------------

Main article: [Sport in Gibraltar](/wiki/Sport_in_Gibraltar "Sport in Gibraltar")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Gibraltar_starting_XI.jpg/220px-Gibraltar_starting_XI.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gibraltar_starting_XI.jpg) The [Gibraltar national football team](/wiki/Gibraltar_national_football_team "Gibraltar national football team") lining up in their first official match, against [Slovakia](/wiki/Slovakia_national_football_team "Slovakia national football team"), in 2013

[Football](/wiki/Football_in_Gibraltar "Football in Gibraltar") is a popular sport in Gibraltar. The [Gibraltar Football Association](/wiki/Gibraltar_Football_Association "Gibraltar Football Association") applied for full membership of [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA"), but their bid was turned down in 2007 in a contentious decision.^[\[146\]](#cite_note-BBC_Sport-150)^ Gibraltar was confirmed as UEFA's 54th member on 24 May 2013 as a result of [Court of Arbitration for Sport](/wiki/Court_of_Arbitration_for_Sport "Court of Arbitration for Sport") (CAS) arbitration and played in [Euro 2016](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016 "UEFA Euro 2016") qualifications.^[\[147\]](#cite_note-151)^^[\[148\]](#cite_note-autogenerated1-152)^ Their first match was a 0--0 draw against Slovakia. Gibraltar's national team won its first-ever match in UEFA competition on 13 October 2018, beating Armenia in the [2018--19 UEFA Nations League D](/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_UEFA_Nations_League_D "2018–19 UEFA Nations League D").^[\[149\]](#cite_note-153)^{#cite_ref-153}

Subsequently, Gibraltar applied for FIFA membership but this bid was also turned down. On 2 May 2016, the CAS upheld the appeal filed by the Gibraltar Football Association regarding its request to become a full-time member of FIFA. CAS ordered FIFA to stop blocking Gibraltar's application for membership and allow it "without delay".^[\[150\]](#cite_note-154)^{#cite_ref-154}

[Rugby union](/wiki/Rugby_union_in_Gibraltar "Rugby union in Gibraltar") is fairly popular and one of the fastest-growing team sports. [Gibraltar Rugby Football Union](/wiki/Gibraltar_Rugby_Football_Union "Gibraltar Rugby Football Union") applied for membership of Europe's governing body for rugby. Gibraltar is believed to be the birthplace of the rugby variant [Tag Rugby](/wiki/Tag_Rugby "Tag Rugby").^[\[151\]](#cite_note-155)^^[\[e\]](#cite_note-156)^{#cite_ref-156}  

Communications {#Communications}
--------------------------------

Main article: [Communications in Gibraltar](/wiki/Communications_in_Gibraltar "Communications in Gibraltar")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Telex1.jpg/220px-Telex1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Telex1.jpg) A plaque in City Mill Lane marking the site of Gibraltar's first telephone exchange [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Victorian_Post_Box_of_1887_in_use_at_Gibraltar_in_2008.jpg/170px-Victorian_Post_Box_of_1887_in_use_at_Gibraltar_in_2008.jpg)](/wiki/File:Victorian_Post_Box_of_1887_in_use_at_Gibraltar_in_2008.jpg) A Victorian post box of standard 1887 UK design in use in Gibraltar's Main Street (2008)

Gibraltar has a digital [telephone exchange](/wiki/Telephone_exchange "Telephone exchange") supported by a [fibre optic](/wiki/Optical_fibre "Optical fibre") and copper infrastructure; the telephone operator [Gibtelecom](/wiki/Gibtelecom "Gibtelecom") also operates a [GSM](/wiki/GSM "GSM") network. Internet connectivity is available across the fixed network. Gibraltar's top-level domain code is [.gi](/wiki/.gi ".gi").

[International Direct Dialling](/wiki/International_Direct_Dialling "International Direct Dialling") (IDD) is provided, and Gibraltar was allocated the access code [+350](/wiki/%2B350 "+350") by the [International Telecommunication Union](/wiki/International_Telecommunication_Union "International Telecommunication Union"). This has been finally accepted by Spain since 10 February 2007, when the [telecom dispute](/wiki/Telecom_dispute_between_Gibraltar_and_Spain "Telecom dispute between Gibraltar and Spain") was resolved.  

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

Main article: [Transport in Gibraltar](/wiki/Transport_in_Gibraltar "Transport in Gibraltar")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Gibraltar_Cable_Car_2.jpg/170px-Gibraltar_Cable_Car_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gibraltar_Cable_Car_2.jpg) The [Gibraltar Cable Car](/wiki/Gibraltar_Cable_Car "Gibraltar Cable Car") runs from outside the [Gibraltar Botanic Gardens](/wiki/Gibraltar_Botanic_Gardens "Gibraltar Botanic Gardens") to the top of the Rock, with an intermediate station at Apes' Den.  

### Road {#Road}

Within Gibraltar, the main form of transport is the car. [Motorcycles](/wiki/Motorcycle "Motorcycle") are also very popular and there is a good modern bus service. Unlike in the UK and other British territories, traffic [drives on the right](/wiki/Right-_and_left-hand_traffic "Right- and left-hand traffic") and speed limits are in km/h, as the territory shares a land border with Spain. The [E15](/wiki/European_route_E15 "European route E15") route connecting with Spain, France, England and Scotland is accessible from the Spanish side using the [CA-34](/wiki/Autov%C3%ADa_CA-34 "Autovía CA-34") [autovía](/wiki/Autov%C3%ADa "Autovía").

Restrictions on transport introduced by Spanish dictator [Francisco Franco](/wiki/Francisco_Franco "Francisco Franco") closed the land frontier in 1969 and also prohibited any air or ferry connections. In 1982, the land border was reopened. As the result of an agreement signed in [Córdoba](/wiki/C%C3%B3rdoba,_Spain "Córdoba, Spain") on 18 September 2006 between Gibraltar, the United Kingdom and Spain,^[\[152\]](#cite_note-cordoba-157)^ the Spanish government agreed to relax [border controls](/wiki/Border_control "Border control") at the frontier that have plagued locals for decades; in return, Britain paid increased pensions to Spanish workers who lost their jobs when Franco closed the border.^[\[153\]](#cite_note-pensions-158)^ Telecommunication restrictions were lifted in February 2007 and air links with Spain were restored in December 2006.^[\[154\]](#cite_note-airport-159)^^[\[155\]](#cite_note-160)^{#cite_ref-160}

Motorists and pedestrians crossing the border with Spain are occasionally subjected to very long delays.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-161)^ Spain has occasionally closed the border during disputes or incidents involving the Gibraltar authorities, such as the [*Aurora* cruise ship incident](/wiki/MV_Aurora_(2000)#Norovirus_breakout "MV Aurora (2000)")^[\[157\]](#cite_note-162)^ and when fishermen from the Spanish fishing vessel *Piraña* were arrested for [illegal fishing](/wiki/Illegal,_unreported_and_unregulated_fishing "Illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing") in Gibraltar waters.^[\[158\]](#cite_note-163)^{#cite_ref-163}  

### Air {#Air}

Main article: [Gibraltar International Airport](/wiki/Gibraltar_International_Airport "Gibraltar International Airport")

As of 2017^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gibraltar&action=edit)^, Gibraltar maintains regular flight connections with London (Heathrow, Gatwick \& Luton), [Manchester](/wiki/Manchester "Manchester") and [Bristol](/wiki/Bristol "Bristol") in the UK, and with [Casablanca](/wiki/Casablanca "Casablanca") and [Tangier](/wiki/Tangier "Tangier") in [Morocco](/wiki/Morocco "Morocco").^[\[159\]](#cite_note-164)^ This is via the [Royal Air Force](/wiki/Royal_Air_Force "Royal Air Force")'s military aerodrome in Gibraltar, which also serves as [the territory's civilian airport](/wiki/Gibraltar_International_Airport "Gibraltar International Airport").^[\[160\]](#cite_note-165)^{#cite_ref-165}

[GB Airways](/wiki/GB_Airways "GB Airways") operated a service between Gibraltar and London and other cities for many years. The airline initially flew under the name "Gibraltar Airways". In 1989, and in anticipation of service to cities outside the UK, Gibraltar Airways changed its name to GB Airways with the belief that a new name would incur fewer political problems. As a franchise, the airline operated flights in full [British Airways](/wiki/British_Airways "British Airways") livery. In 2007, GB Airways was purchased by [easyJet](/wiki/EasyJet "EasyJet"),^[\[161\]](#cite_note-166)^ which began operating flights under their name in April 2008 when British Airways re-introduced flights to Gibraltar under their name. EasyJet have since added [Bristol](/wiki/Bristol_Airport "Bristol Airport") and [Manchester](/wiki/Manchester_Airport "Manchester Airport") and also operated flights to [Liverpool](/wiki/Liverpool_Airport "Liverpool Airport") between 2011 and 2012. Until entering administration in October 2017, [Monarch Airlines](/wiki/Monarch_Airlines "Monarch Airlines") operated the largest number of flights between the United Kingdom and Gibraltar, with scheduled services between Gibraltar and [Luton](/wiki/London_Luton_Airport "London Luton Airport"), [London Gatwick](/wiki/Gatwick_Airport "Gatwick Airport"), [Birmingham](/wiki/Birmingham_Airport "Birmingham Airport") and [Manchester](/wiki/Manchester_Airport "Manchester Airport"). The Spanish [national airline](/wiki/National_airline "National airline"), [Iberia](/wiki/Iberia_Airlines "Iberia Airlines"), operated a daily service to [Madrid](/wiki/Barajas_Airport "Barajas Airport") which ceased for lack of demand. In May 2009, [Ándalus Líneas Aéreas](/wiki/%C3%81ndalus_L%C3%ADneas_A%C3%A9reas "Ándalus Líneas Aéreas") opened a Spanish service,^[\[162\]](#cite_note-167)^ which also ceased operations in March 2010.^[\[163\]](#cite_note-168)^ An annual return [charter flight](/wiki/Charter_flight "Charter flight") to [Malta](/wiki/Malta_International_Airport "Malta International Airport") is operated by [Maltese](/wiki/Malta "Malta") national airline, [Air Malta](/wiki/Air_Malta "Air Malta").{#cite_ref-168}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Gibraltar_Airport_main_runway_with_4-lane_road_crossing.jpg/220px-Gibraltar_Airport_main_runway_with_4-lane_road_crossing.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gibraltar_Airport_main_runway_with_4-lane_road_crossing.jpg) The main road that crosses Gibraltar Airport [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Gibraltar_Airport_New_Terminal.jpg/220px-Gibraltar_Airport_New_Terminal.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gibraltar_Airport_New_Terminal.jpg) The new terminal at Gibraltar Airport

[Gibraltar International Airport](/wiki/Gibraltar_Airport "Gibraltar Airport") is unusual not only because of its proximity to the city centre resulting in the airport terminal being within walking distance of much of Gibraltar but also because the runway intersects [Winston Churchill Avenue](/wiki/Winston_Churchill_Avenue,_Gibraltar "Winston Churchill Avenue, Gibraltar"), formerly the main road into Spain, requiring movable barricades to close when aircraft land or depart. New roads and a tunnel, ending the need to stop road traffic when aircraft use the runway, were planned to coincide with the building of a new [airport terminal building](/wiki/Gibraltar_Airport#New_terminal "Gibraltar Airport") with an originally estimated completion date of 2009,^[\[164\]](#cite_note-pressnote-169)^^[\[165\]](#cite_note-170)^ although delays pushed back its official opening until 31 March 2023.^[\[166\]](#cite_note-171)^^[\[167\]](#cite_note-172)^ The new road and tunnel is named Kingsway with the approval of [Charles III](/wiki/Charles_III "Charles III")^[\[168\]](#cite_note-173)^ and passes under the terminal and the eastern edge of the runway before connecting with [Devil's Tower Road](/wiki/Devil%27s_Tower_Road "Devil's Tower Road"). Runway access is now closed to everyday road traffic but is still available for exceptional, specific, or emergency use as well as pedestrians, cyclists and mobility scooters although an alternative subway is provided.^[\[169\]](#cite_note-174)^{#cite_ref-174}

The most popular alternative airport for Gibraltar is [Málaga Airport](/wiki/M%C3%A1laga_Airport "Málaga Airport") in Spain, some 120 km (75 mi) to the east, which offers a wide range of destinations, second to [Jerez Airport](/wiki/Jerez_Airport "Jerez Airport") which is closer to Gibraltar. In addition, the [Algeciras Heliport](/wiki/Algeciras_Heliport "Algeciras Heliport") across the bay offers scheduled services to [Ceuta](/wiki/Ceuta "Ceuta").  

### Sea {#Sea}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Europa_Point_Lighthouse.jpg/220px-Europa_Point_Lighthouse.jpg)](/wiki/File:Europa_Point_Lighthouse.jpg) [Europa Point Lighthouse](/wiki/Europa_Point_Lighthouse "Europa Point Lighthouse"), located at the southernmost tip of the Gibraltar peninsula

[Gibraltar Cruise Terminal](/wiki/Gibraltar_Cruise_Terminal "Gibraltar Cruise Terminal") receives a large number of visits from [cruise ships](/wiki/Cruise_ship "Cruise ship"). The [Strait of Gibraltar](/wiki/Strait_of_Gibraltar "Strait of Gibraltar") is one of the busiest shipping lanes in the world.

Passenger and cargo ships anchor in the [Gibraltar Harbour](/wiki/Gibraltar_Harbour "Gibraltar Harbour"). Also, a ferry links Gibraltar with [Tangier](/wiki/Tangier "Tangier") in Morocco. The ferry between Gibraltar and [Algeciras](/wiki/Algeciras "Algeciras"), which had been halted in 1969 when Franco severed communications with Gibraltar, was reopened on 16 December 2009, served by the Spanish company [Transcoma](/w/index.php?title=Transcoma&action=edit&redlink=1 "Transcoma (page does not exist)").^[\[170\]](#cite_note-175)^ A vehicle ramp at the western end of the North Mole allows vehicles to be unloaded from a [RORO](/wiki/Roll-on/roll-off "Roll-on/roll-off") ferry.^[\[171\]](#cite_note-176)^{#cite_ref-176}

Ferries by FRS running twice a week from Gibraltar to [Tanger-Med](/wiki/Tanger-Med "Tanger-Med") port provide access to the [Moroccan railway](/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Morocco "Rail transport in Morocco") system.^[\[172\]](#cite_note-177)^^[\[173\]](#cite_note-178)^{#cite_ref-178}  

### Rail {#Rail}

Nothing remains of the two [former railway systems](/wiki/Transport_in_Gibraltar#Rail "Transport in Gibraltar") within Gibraltar.

On the Spanish side of the border, railway track extends to the outskirts of [La Línea](/wiki/La_L%C3%ADnea_de_la_Concepci%C3%B3n "La Línea de la Concepción") from an [aborted rail expansion project in the 1970s](/wiki/San_Roque-La_L%C3%ADnea_railway "San Roque-La Línea railway"),^[\[174\]](#cite_note-179)^^[\[175\]](#cite_note-180)^ but the closest operational railway station in Spain is [San Roque station](/wiki/San_Roque_station "San Roque station"), accessible via buses from [La Línea](/wiki/La_L%C3%ADnea_de_la_Concepci%C3%B3n "La Línea de la Concepción").{#cite_ref-180}  

Water supply and sanitation {#Water_supply_and_sanitation}
----------------------------------------------------------

Main article: [Water supply and sanitation in Gibraltar](/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Gibraltar "Water supply and sanitation in Gibraltar")

[Water supply](/wiki/Water_supply "Water supply") and [sanitation](/wiki/Sanitation "Sanitation") in Gibraltar have been major concerns for its inhabitants throughout its history. There are no rivers, streams, or large bodies of water on the peninsula. Gibraltar's water supply was formerly provided by a combination of an aqueduct, wells, and the use of cisterns, barrels and earthenware pots to capture rainwater. This became increasingly inadequate as Gibraltar's population grew in the 18th and 19th centuries and lethal diseases such as [cholera](/wiki/Cholera "Cholera") and [yellow fever](/wiki/Yellow_fever "Yellow fever") began to spread. In the late 19th century, a Sanitary Commission instigated major improvements which saw the introduction of large-scale desalination and the use of giant water catchments covering over 2.5 million square feet (nearly 250,000 m^2^). Today Gibraltar's supply of drinking water comes entirely from [desalination](/wiki/Desalination "Desalination"), with a separate supply of saltwater for sanitary purposes. Both supplies are delivered from huge underground reservoirs excavated under the [Rock of Gibraltar](/wiki/Rock_of_Gibraltar "Rock of Gibraltar").  

Police {#Police}
----------------

Further information: [Royal Gibraltar Police](/wiki/Royal_Gibraltar_Police "Royal Gibraltar Police") and [Gibraltar Defence Police](/wiki/Gibraltar_Defence_Police "Gibraltar Defence Police")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/RGP_Patrol_Car.JPG/220px-RGP_Patrol_Car.JPG)](/wiki/File:RGP_Patrol_Car.JPG) Royal Gibraltar Police car, 2012 [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/K20P1600.JPG/220px-K20P1600.JPG)](/wiki/File:K20P1600.JPG) [Royal Gibraltar Police](/wiki/Royal_Gibraltar_Police "Royal Gibraltar Police"), Marine Section

The [Royal Gibraltar Police](/wiki/Royal_Gibraltar_Police "Royal Gibraltar Police") (RGP), [Gibraltar Defence Police](/wiki/Gibraltar_Defence_Police "Gibraltar Defence Police") (GDP) and [His Majesty's Customs (Gibraltar)](/wiki/His_Majesty%27s_Customs_(Gibraltar) "His Majesty's Customs (Gibraltar)") are Gibraltar's principal civilian [law enforcement agencies](/wiki/Law_enforcement_agency "Law enforcement agency"). Outside the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"), the RGP is the oldest police force of the former [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire"), formed shortly after the creation of London's [Metropolitan Police](/wiki/Metropolitan_Police "Metropolitan Police") in 1829 when Gibraltar was declared a [crown colony](/wiki/Crown_colony "Crown colony") on 25 June 1830.^[\[176\]](#cite_note-181)^{#cite_ref-181}

In general, the Gibraltar force follows British police models in its dress and its mostly male constables and sergeants on foot patrol wear the traditional [custodian helmet](/wiki/Custodian_helmet "Custodian helmet"), the headgear of the British "bobby on the beat". The helmet is traditionally made of cork covered outside by felt or [serge](/wiki/Serge_(fabric) "Serge (fabric)")-like material that matches the tunic. The vehicles also appear virtually identical to typical UK police vehicles, but are [left hand drive](/wiki/Left_hand_drive "Left hand drive").

The force, whose name received the prefix "Royal" in 1992, numbers over 220 officers divided into a number of units.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ These include the [CID](/wiki/Criminal_Investigation_Department "Criminal Investigation Department"), drug squad, [special branch](/wiki/Special_branch "Special branch"), firearms, [scene of crime examiners](/wiki/Scenes_of_Crime_Officer "Scenes of Crime Officer"), traffic, marine and operations units, sections or departments.

On 24 September 2015, the Freedom of the City of Gibraltar was conferred upon the RGP by the Mayor, Adolfo Canepa.  

Armed forces {#Armed_forces}
----------------------------

The defence of Gibraltar, as a British territory, is the responsibility of the *national* (i.e., British) government, with its tri-services [British Forces Gibraltar](/wiki/British_Forces_Gibraltar "British Forces Gibraltar"):

* The [Royal Gibraltar Regiment](/wiki/Royal_Gibraltar_Regiment "Royal Gibraltar Regiment") provides the army garrison with a detachment of the [British Army](/wiki/British_Army "British Army"), based at [Devil's Tower Camp](/wiki/Devil%27s_Tower_Camp "Devil's Tower Camp").^[\[177\]](#cite_note-182)^ The regiment was originally a part-time reserve force until the British Army placed it on a permanent footing in 1990. The regiment includes full-time and part-time soldiers recruited from Gibraltar as well as British Army regulars posted from other regiments.{#cite_ref-182}
* The [Royal Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy") maintains a [squadron of several patrol vessels and craft](/wiki/Gibraltar_Squadron "Gibraltar Squadron") at the Rock. The squadron is responsible for the security and integrity of British Gibraltar Territorial Waters (BGTW). The shore establishment at Gibraltar is called [HMS *Rooke*](/wiki/HMS_Rooke "HMS Rooke") after [Sir George Rooke](/wiki/Sir_George_Rooke "Sir George Rooke"), who captured the Rock for [Archduke Charles](/wiki/Charles_VI,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Charles VI, Holy Roman Emperor") (pretender to the Spanish throne) in 1704. The naval air base was named HMS *Cormorant.* Gibraltar's strategic position provides an important facility for the Royal Navy and Britain's allies. British and US nuclear submarines frequently visit the *Z berths* at Gibraltar.^[\[178\]](#cite_note-183)^ A [Z berth](/wiki/Berth_(moorings) "Berth (moorings)") provides the facility for nuclear submarines to visit for operational or recreational purposes and for non-nuclear repairs. During the [Falklands War](/wiki/Falklands_War "Falklands War"), an Argentine plan to attack British shipping in the harbour using frogmen ([Operation Algeciras](/wiki/Operation_Algeciras "Operation Algeciras")) was foiled.^[\[179\]](#cite_note-184)^ The naval base also played a part in supporting the task force sent by Britain to recover the Falklands.{#cite_ref-184}
* The [Royal Air Force](/wiki/Royal_Air_Force "Royal Air Force") station at Gibraltar forms part of Headquarters British Forces Gibraltar. Although aircraft are no longer permanently stationed at [RAF Gibraltar](/wiki/RAF_Gibraltar "RAF Gibraltar"), a variety of RAF aircraft make regular visits and the airfield also houses a section from the [Met Office](/wiki/Met_Office "Met Office"). The [Gibraltar Air Cadets](/wiki/Gibraltar_Air_Cadets "Gibraltar Air Cadets") is an active squadron.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-185)^{#cite_ref-185}

In January 2007, the Ministry of Defence announced that the private company [Serco](/wiki/Serco "Serco") would provide services to the base. The announcement resulted in extensive negotiations with the relevant trade unions.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-186)^^[\[182\]](#cite_note-187)^{#cite_ref-187}

Gibraltar has an important role in [signals intelligence gathering](/wiki/Signals_intelligence "Signals intelligence"), serving as a vital strategic part of the United Kingdom communications gathering and monitoring network in the Mediterranean and North Africa.^[\[183\]](#cite_note-188)^^[\[184\]](#cite_note-189)^{#cite_ref-189}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Gibraltar_navy.jpg/220px-Gibraltar_navy.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gibraltar_navy.jpg) The [Royal Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy")'s base in Gibraltar

Historically, Gibraltar was one of four [Imperial fortress](/wiki/Imperial_fortress "Imperial fortress") colonies, along with [Bermuda](/wiki/Bermuda "Bermuda"), [Halifax, Nova Scotia](/wiki/Halifax,_Nova_Scotia "Halifax, Nova Scotia") and [Malta](/wiki/Malta "Malta").
